title: Will any country actually use a nuclear weapon ever? If yes then which one? - Quora

response.answer_text: Back in the early 90's there was a story aired on the early morning live NPR broadcast from Washington that said the CIA had confirmed reports of a Soviet Air Force fighter plane firing an air to air nuclear missile at an Afghan Air Force met. The report said there was a blue-white flash and the Afghan aircraft disappeared with no debris falling to the ground. According to the report, a CIA Agent witnessed the event. I'd been on my way to work in LA when this aired at 0300 Pacific Time. When I picked up my coworker I mentioned the story, he was very interested to hear it. When the rebroadcast came on, the segment on the event had been removed, something we both found interesting. So apparently, the Soviets were the second to use nuclear weapons.

While a lot of people are saying North Korea I would say Russia. While North Korea is unstable their use of nuclear weapons would literally guarantee their countries down fall. Russia is more stable for sure however Putin has said he would use nuclear weapons in a first strike. He has also said he would use them to de-escalate conflicts. For example if NATO built up troops on the Russian border they might use a nuclear bomb on them to stop an attack even if war isn’t declared. Anoth huge reason Russia might launch first is an accident. We know Russia is behind on all military aspects after the Cold War so the nuclear weapons probably arnt all up to date. Yes I know they brag about how the keep updating their nukes but how serious are they? Have they updated all 2,000 ICBMs? I doubt it. The threat of an accidental launch is worryingly high. Maybe a computer detects a launch from the US and Russian officials decide to counter launch. This is becoming more unlikely by the day due to new technology but it’s still a possibility. The main possibility is a computer launch. Where the computer launches a nuke on its own. Russia doesn’t have as many safety nets as the US. Once a ICBM is launched there is no backing out (I have no clue why nations don’t have an explosive on board the missile to stop it if needed). While North Korea likes to boast its nukes it likely won’t use them. Russia probably wouldn’t use them as a first strike but the possibility is there especially since the president alone decides to launch. I hope an accident launch or a launch on purpose happens but the chances are all ways there when nuclear weapons exist.

The question is really, “which country is most likely to use nuclear weapons NEXT?” The U.S. has already used them, at the end of World War II. The most probable next user right now is Pakistan, either in another conflict with India, or in a campaign supporting the Taliban and Chechen rebels against Russia. Pakistan has a long history of political instability, and an internal quasi-government — the secretive ISI — which often has its own agenda. Next in line, as soon as their bombs are ready, are the mullahs of Iran. They won’t wait until their arsenal matches Israel’s. They will strike as soon and as viciously as they can to annihilate their hated foe. Nuclear devices don’t need fancy weapons systems to deliver their death, after all. A passenger jet, a heavy truck, or a cargo ship can work just as well. The Israelis are very uneasy, and rightfully so. The old men in Qom won’t rest until they are radioactive dust. After that, its a crap shoot that may include nations with programs we don’t currently know about. The Turks, in their blind hatred for the Kurds, might buy or build a bomb. The Saudi Sheiks might buy enough to end Houthi aggression in Yemen. The world is becoming a very dangerous place.
